channel.description: Recent content in Productivity on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Humans are just animals with slightly better cognitive capabilities. This is important to remember, as it determines everything about how we think and work.

item.title: Motivation
item.description: Motivation is a fickle mistress. You cannot directly control it, yet we always keep waiting for it to appear.

item.title: Discipline
item.description: Ah, discipline. Surely this is the answer to all our troubles, right? Motivation was a fickle mistress, but discipline can be trained and consistently applied!

item.title: Habits
item.description: Humans are creatures of habit. If we do the same thing a few mornings in a row, it has now become a habit.

item.title: Environment
item.description: I already explained how all humans are lazy, by nature, and there’s no sense fighting that. Instead of fighting, though, we can use laziness to our advantage!

item.title: Subconscious beats conscious
item.description: Let me explain this idea by using an important example from my own life. After a car accident, I struggled a lot with posture.

item.title: Small beats big
item.description: You’re probably reading this guide on productivity because you have big ideas, ambitions, desires that you want to fulfill.

item.title: Do beats Don't
item.description: Doubt. Doubt is the killer of all human dreams. It’s certainly the killer of many things in my life, both in terms of productivity and life choices.

item.title: First beats Last
item.description: This one is related to the “doubt” from the last chapter. Doubt accumulates. The more time you give it, the more it builds and builds.

item.title: Sleep beats All
item.description: The title says it all. Our mind and body work in wondrous ways. And their most important resource? Time.

item.title: Community beats Ego
item.description: At the start of this guide, I talked about motivation not being consistent, and people naturally struggling with it.

item.title: Iteration beats perfectionism
item.description: This one will be short, as I already mentioned this several times. Any thing you do … you can do again.

item.title: Singletasking beats Multitasking
item.description: I fell into this trap big time when I was young. I created systems for myself in which I would constantly work on multiple things at the same time.

item.title: Excuses
item.description: Your head probably formulated many excuses and counter arguments, as you read this course. All sorts of reasons why the rules don’t apply to you.

item.title: Tips & Tricks
item.description: Lastly, I wanted to talk about some tricks or lessons that didn’t fit elsewhere in this guide. They are mostly related to what worked for me.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Pfew, many tips and examples, but you made it through. In this last chapter, let’s summarize and talk more about applying this in practice.
